comment._content: From the Smithsonian's own website, to left of Einstein, with hand-in-jacket, is Albert Abraham Michelson and to the right is Robert Andrews Millikan.  Tags added.

comment._content: Albert Einstein has the best hair out of all of them.

comment.author: 48600109393@N01
comment._content: The date is the earliest possible date, given when Einstein was born. Michelson died in 1931, and it's unikely that this was taken before Einstein's relativity was widely accepted after the first world war, so I'd suggest this is most likely to be during the 1920s.

comment.author: 12511291@N07
comment._content: I absolutely love this photograph. I love how Einstein is completely different from the rest of the men in the group, with his hair all long and disheveled, and staring off into the distance instead of looking at the camera lol..... a true genius...

comment.author: 92447377@N00
comment._content: The photo is clearly taken in front of the Athenaeum on the campus of the California Institute of Technology (Caltech).  It was probably taken during the time that Einstein was at Caltech.

comment.author: 48600109393@N01
comment._content:
From the pages on the Nobel Prize's site about the History of Caltech:
The list of scientists who accepted Millikan's invitation represented the cream of European physics, including Paul Dirac, Erwin Schrödinger, Werner Heisenberg, Hendrik Lorentz, and Niels Bohr. Albert Einstein's visits to the campus in 1931, 1932, and 1933 capped Millikan's plans to put physics on the map in southern California
Looks like I was aiming for the wrong decade.

comment.author: 83194813@N00
comment._content:
A few more of the names are given here: photos.aip.org/searchResult2.jsp?item_id=Einstein Albert D5&fname=einstein_albert_d5.jpg&title=null&description=L-R: Adams, Michelson, Einstein's assistant Walther Meyer, Einstein, Max Farrand of the Huntington Library, Millikan standing Pasadena&credit=Photograph by William Kellogg, California Institute of Technology, courtesy AIP Emilio Segre Visual Archives&photoDate=null&storePublished=Y&color=null&names=Adams, Walter Sydney; Einstein, Albert; Michelson, Albert Abraham; Millikan, Robert Andrews&contactID=null
L-R: Adams, Michelson, Einstein's assistant Walther Meyer, Einstein, Max Farrand of the Huntington Library, Millikan
Given the dates of Einstein's visits to Caltech and the date of Michelson's death, it seems clear that this was taken in 1931.

comment.author: 42264328@N00
comment._content: I wanted to second VegGeek's identification of the location--almost certainly the Caltech Athenaeum. Caltech has a lot of historical archives, and the Einstein visits were documented--Smithsonian should be able to contact them and probably get an exact date on the photo: Aha! Same photo is here on the Caltech archives. The date is given as 1931, as surmised above. Caption reads--replicating information given above, mostly: Three Nobel Prize winners: Einstein, Millikan, Michelson 1931 Front row: A. A. Michelson, Albert Einstein, Robert A. Millikan; back row: Walter S. Adams, Walther Mayer, Max Ferrrand. Photo was taken in front of the Athenaeum Photo ID 1.9-1 The Caltech archivist should have more information.

comment.author: 36519414@N00
comment._content: This photo is copied here : commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Image:Portrait_of_Albert_Einst...

comment.author: 98237810@N00
comment._content: The The Emilio Segrè Visual Archives, part of the Niels Bohr Library of the Center for History of Physics at the American Institute of Physics, credits the photographer as William Kellogg, California Institute of Technology.

comment.author: 42264328@N00
comment._content: earthsound--very interesting about photographer "William Kellogg". It is hard to find information on him because of the similarity of the name with that of the industrialist W.K. Kellogg, after whom the Kellogg Radiation Laboratory at Caltech is named. I don't think the industrialist took the photo, but I suppose that is possible! (Or could this just be a mistake in the photo credit, that it was from someone at the Kellogg lab at Caltech?) I did find one reference to a "William Kellogg", a meteorologist, in this NASA History document, but it is not clear if this is the same person as the putative photographer. I like the "Kellogg Lab" idea somewhat better.

comment.author: 7576993@N07
comment._content: Thank you for taking the time to comment on our photo! Since these photos were acquired from various print dealers by our donor, Bern Dibner, in the 1940’s, our records for the collection are a bit sparse. Your comments have been extremely valuable in helping us update information for this image. As you can see, we have already added the 1931 date!

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: On Page 132 of the book The Einstein scrapbook By Ze'ev Rosenkranz, Bet ha-sefarim ha-leʼumi ṿeha-universiṭaʼi bi-Yerushalayim Albert Einstein Archives Published by JHU Press, 2002 ISBN 0801872030, 9780801872037 This photograph is credited as being in front of the Athenaeum, Caltech on January 7, 1931. The book's author is also visiting associate in History and visiting editor for the Einstein Papers Project at the California Institute of Technology, and is the former Bern Dibner curator of the Albert Einstein Archives at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, so I guess he knows whereof he speaks. Further ref for the book here: www.press.jhu.edu/books/title_pages/2581.html The relevant page of the book may also be viewed via Google Book Search.

comment.author: 7576993@N07
comment._content: Thank you for that reference, lifeasdaddy.  Although we currently do not have staff available to do further research, your comment will be very helpful when we update the information for this image.

comment.author: 63301670@N05
comment._content: I found an old La Corona cigar box in a room full of dusty discarded lab items from the 30s in the basement of HEP at Cal Tech in the mid 80's. It has a 1932 date on the customs stamp. I know Einstein smoked a pipe which he is hiding in his hand in the photograph, but he was also known to enjoy a fine Havana cigar from time to time. I also know he was there in 1932 and 1933. I still have the box and every once in awhile I imagine him enjoying one of these fine cigars during one of his stays at Cal Tech.
